Expectation1: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation1: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: This morning, as I finished my prayers, Sister Agnes rushed in, her face pale. “The Martinez family’s house burned down last night. They have nothing left.” My heart clenched. As a nun, I am called to serve those in need, to be present in moments of crisis. I gathered food and clothing from the convent’s pantry, ready to bring comfort to the family. But as I loaded the supplies into my car, my phone buzzed—a reminder for my volunteer shift at the community center. I was expected to be there in twenty minutes, punctual as always. The center relies on me, but I know other volunteers are already there and could cover for a while. Still, I feel the weight of my commitment; I promised to be dependable. The Martinez family needs me now, but so does the center. My hands tremble as I grip the steering wheel, torn between the urgent suffering before me and the quiet, steady promise I made elsewhere.
